Topic.Title: Only 1 out of 10 Galaxy 4S is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5 octa

Message.Msg: The first Exynos 5 used the Mali T604, not the Mali 400 series. The Octo made the curious choice of switching to the PowerVR. The Mali T600 series was introduced in November 2010. It took two years before the first chip used it, and it immediately switched away. I believe that there are currently no other chips using the 600 series, despite a whole series listed on ARMH's website. Errrm, let me restate that: "They are well positioned for future design wins, with multiple implementations in the pipeline." T

Topic.Title: Only 1 out of 10 Galaxy 4S is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5 octa

Message.Msg: 'The first Exynos 5 used the Mali T604' which was about 4W under load which is probably why it was dropped.

Message.Title: downloaded games up 16%, packaged games fall 21%
Message.Msg: U.S. retail sales of packaged video games fell 21 percent last year to $8.9 billion, according to researcher NPD Group, while revenue from games downloaded to computers and mobile devices rose 16 percent to $5.9 billion.

Topic.Title: Only 1 out of 10 Galaxy 4S is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5 octa

Message.Msg: as it currently stands, there is only a very narrow market segment that can use the t3i - non aapl, sammy feature phones. That segment will be under siege from aapl within 2 months when aapl swims downstream for growth with a cheaper iPhone. Translated, nvda brought nothing unique to the party and will leave with a totally empty stomach while everybody feasted at the mobile table. nvda's best shot was the t3, even when it couldn't yield 1.8g,the 1.2G, with a one year lead and reference low cost Kai design kit, should have done something. When it failed, that just laid bare all the wrong assumptions on the market Jen has been chasing with megabucks.

Topic.Title: Nvidia not interested in Apple or Samsung business

Message.Msg: it's not defeatist talk, it's the reality. Reality no doubt forced on them when the whole investment world knows about it and Jen finally had to swallow that canary or appear totally out of touch/stupid. You know, if I were to place ultimate blame, I would place it on Jen's loud mouth. Not only does he not have anything unique to loud mouth with, but after such a graphic lesson on IBM yielding all the value added to msft and intc, Jen started out by saying he would own the ARM proc market and create himself a monopoly. No oem would ever sign up to that, hence nobody big would go with nvda chips. As I said, next up: wearables. Space is more than at a premium, it is non-existing. Would be an interesting fight there. Right, a hot T4 on your watch and brand you wrist with the nvda logo... now that will be a 'hot' seller, pun intended.

Message.Title: real life observation of proc performance counts for naught
Message.Msg: I would guess 25% of users on the metro here in montreal are on some kind of device, a lot of times playing games. a couple of days ago, I spotted a girl sitting next to me playing games on a phone. That phone was extra responsive, like absolutely nothing that I've seen before. Its speed absolutely stood out. It was that good. It was a htc phone. I had no doubt it must have be 1.6G T3 powered. Even with a product like that, how did htc do last Q? The whole assumption here that 10% higher bench mark would win the day just isn't so. It would win bragging rights on this nothing forum, but nothing else out there in the real world.

Topic.Title: Nvidia not interested in Apple or Samsung business

Message.Msg: As a shareholder, I am not really interested in seeing NVDA pay people to try to convince Apple not to use the A series chips. Why? Think it would work today? NVDA is and should be focusing on great chips and let them do the talking. It might be worth talking to Apple in a chip generation or two, but not right now.

Topic.Title: Rumor: Nvidia marketing team jumps ship to AMD

Message.Msg: I wouldn't call him too important, or a great loss. He was a Mktg Manager who understands positioning and strengths and weaknesses. It wasn't like it was Nick Stam or something. He was from Austin, not Santa Clara where the real action is. AMD can have him as far as I'm concerned.

Topic.Title: Anandtech reports: NV's technival marketing manager Sean Pelletier will join AMD for a similar appointment

Message.Msg: There is always a significant level of personal influx in major corporations - those who have been there know this for a fact - no matter how successful the companies are. I would get concerned if JH left...or Bill Dalley. No one else is indispensable as far as this investor is concerned. I posted the Anandtech source link just for information sharing, not necessarily believe it was a earth-shaking piece of news like the bashers/shorts would want you to believe.

Topic.Title: Anandtech reports: NV's technival marketing manager Sean Pelletier will join AMD for a similar appointment

Message.Msg: I'm sure there was a boatload of $, options and a multi year contract involved. That's what it'd take for me to go to work for Rory and a company with little future prospects other than years of just scraping by...

Topic.Title: Anandtech reports: NV's technival marketing manager Sean Pelletier will join AMD for a similar appointment

Message.Msg: People forget that, just in the past couple of years, NVIDA nabbed several AMD/ATI senior engineers and execs in critical areas. Levels of responsibilities held by these AMD exodus seem much higher than a tech marketing manager going in the opposite direction from NVIDIA.

Message.Title: A much more significant loss for AMD: Eric Demers (CTO of Graphics Unit) departed in February, 2013
Message.Msg: anandtechDOTcom/show/5538/amds-eric-demers-is-leaving-the-company The latest of a long string of top-echelon losses.

Topic.Title: Rumor: Nvidia marketing team jumps ship to AMD

Message.Msg: So, the marketing guru, who likely had a hand in such strategies as "we didn't want the consoles anyway" has left for AMD... meanwhile, AMD lost its graphic CTO. So, AMD is losing technical talent and loading up on marketing. Actually, that seems in-line for a company like AMD that is focused on near-term survival, doesn't it?

Topic.Title: Rumor: Nvidia marketing team jumps ship to AMD
Rumor: Nvidia marketing team jumps ship to AMD

Message.Msg: To put things in proper perspectives: --Sean Pellelier was no guru. --He was "a technical marketing manager for NOTEBOOKS" - notebooks only. His previous comments on other NV products were likely irrelevant, merely reflecting his own opinions. Aren't we a bit too lavish with adjectives and words sometimes? :)

Topic.Title: Rumor: Nvidia marketing team jumps ship to AMD

Message.Msg: lol, look at ibey spin em fast and furious. At first I couldn't understand why, one clog gone, just replace by another clog, case closed. But, this clog, this one clog is very different. Gamer cards, chips do the talking. Lose Tegra technical mktg, good riddance. But notepad, notepad is a completely different story. The last two years, notepad was definitely a battleground which nvda handily won against ati + IvyBridge/SandyBridge. This guy must have been instrumental. Losing this guy is a real loss. Ala ibey spinning em fast and furious. Ibey, you should have just let sleeping dogs lie and nobody would have been the wiser. But..... lol, you let the canary out of the bag and you commandante is going to have to swallow this canary. Again.

Topic.Title: SAMSUNG IS THE SMARTEST MANAGEMENT ON PLANET EARTH: THEIR BUSINESS IS TO SELL GADGETS

Message.Msg: Sravann Kundojjala, senior analyst with Strategy Analytics, pointed out that the Chinese vendors are selling dual-core ARM chips at $4 or $5 and quad-cores at $8 or $9, less than half what Nvidia is selling its equivalent chips for and so probably the Chinese vendors, while significant in volume, do not yet have 10 percent of the market by value. London Calling: Did Allwinner outsell Intel, Qualcomm? ARM Inside. EE Times London Calling: Did Allwinner outsell Intel, Qualcomm? Peter Clarke 5/8/2013 11:07 AM EDT (ARM Inside)
